name: ammonium nitrate production | ammonium nitrate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23802/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of ammonium nitrate (AN) with 33.5% N. Ammonium nitrate (formula NH4NO3), is a salt of ammonia and nitric acid, used widely in fertilisers and explosive. The commercial grade contains about 33.5 percent nitrogen (N), all of which is in forms utilizable by plants. Ammonium nitrate is produced through the neutralisation of aqueous nitric acid by gaseous ammonia. The production process comprises three main unit operations: neutralisation, evaporation, and solidification (prilling and granulation). In recent years, energy utilisation has improved extensively through the introduction of pressure neutralisers with recycling and heat recovery. The neutralisation reaction as the first process step is strongly exothermic. In the second step, the evaporation, a solution is formed at a high concentration and the excess water is evaporated. The last step, the solidification, makes the ammonium nitrate into prills or granules.;Ammonium nitrate is a colourless crystalline substance (melting point 169.6 째C). It is highly soluble in water; heating of the water solution decomposes the salt to nitrous oxide (laughing gas).;The main data sources for this dataset are Fertilizers Europe (2014, 2016). Additional data sources are listed as follows.;References:;Fertilizers Europe (2000): Best Available Techniques for Pollution Prevention and Control in the European Fertilizer Industry. Booklet No. 1 of 8: Production of Ammonia. Fertilizers Europe, Brussels.;Kongshaug G. (1998): Energy Consumption and Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Fertilizer Production. IFA 20th July 1998;Davies J., Haglund C. (1999): Life Cycle Inventory of Fertiliser Production. SIK-Report No 654 1999. Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden.;Fertilizers Europe (2000): Best Available Techniques for Pollution Prevention and Control in the European Fertilizer Industry. Booklet No. 2 of 8: Production of Nitric Acid. Fertilizers Europe, Brussels.;Patyk R., Reinhardt, G.A. (1997): D체ngemittel - Energie- und Stoffstrombilanzen. Vieweg Verlag, Braunschweig.;Fertilizers Europe (2014): Average Emissions Year 2011. Fertilizers Europe Environmental report (internal).;Fertilizers Europe (2016): Carbon Footprint Calculator for Fertilizer Production. Specification. Version 2.1;Fertilizers Europe (2016): Average Emissions Year 2014. Fertilizers Europe Environmental report (internal). Used for updated energy and GHG emission in Carbon Footprint Calculator;Fertilizers Europe (2000): Best Available Techniques for Pollution Prevention and Control in the European Fertilizer Industry. Booklet No. 6 of 8: Production of Ammonium Nitrate and Calcium Ammonium Nitrate. Fertilizers Europe, Brussels.;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA D체bendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, D체bendorf, CH.

The activity includes all the raw and processed materials necessary to produce this product. Liquid ammonia, nitric acid, heat (as natural gas and fuel oil) and electricity are included. Direct emissions include ammonia and particulate matter to air and nitrogen to water.

The activity ends with the final product being ready for transportation at the production site.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Primary data were collected on fertiliser production for the year 2011. These data were based on annual average data for the year 2011.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The dataset is representative of ammonia nitrate production in North America, adapted from data collected in European fertiliser plants.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This datasets corresponds to the technology used in North American fertiliser plants. The production of ammonium nitrate involves the combination of liquid ammonia with nitric acid, using heat and electricity.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The data were extrapolated from respective data for the geography of Europe, i.e.  production of ammonia and nitric acid are adapted to reflect production in North America.
